item.title: The New MAGA Megadonors: OpenAI's Greg Brockman and His Wife Anna
item.description:
How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors
In November, Greg Brockman, OpenAI’s president and co-founder, and his wife, Anna, enjoyed a glitzy night out in Washington: a White House state dinner for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The Brockmans were among a broad contingent of tech elite in attendance at the fete, hosted by President Donald Trump. Soon after the event, the Brockmans posted pictures of themselves posing with Elon Musk, Nvidia’s Jensen Huang and his wife, Lori, and David Sacks, the venture capitalist who’s become Trump’s AI and crypto czar. It wasn’t the only time in the last few months that the Silicon Valley couple has made splashy appearances in Trump’s orbit. In the fall, they attended two other White House suppers and went to Trump’s revamped Kennedy Center Honors, dining later that evening with one of the honorees, actor Sylvester Stallone. But nothing has more loudly announced their arrival as Trump-friendly figures than their decision to become megadonors: giving $50 million to Leading the Future, a bipartisan super PAC focused on combating state-level AI regulation, and $25 million to MAGA Inc., a Trump super PAC.
Jan 23, 2026

The Big Read

How Greg and Anna Brockman Became MAGA Megadonors

By Jemima McEvoy, Stephanie Palazzolo, and Sylvia Varnham O'Regan

In November, Greg Brockman, OpenAI’s president and co-founder, and his wife, Anna, enjoyed a glitzy night out in Washington: a White House state dinner for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

The Brockmans were among a broad contingent of tech elite in attendance at the fete, hosted by President Donald Trump. Soon after the event, the Brockmans posted pictures of themselves posing with Elon Musk, Nvidia’s Jensen Huang and his wife, Lori, and David Sacks, the venture capitalist who’s become Trump’s AI and crypto czar.

It wasn’t the only time in the last few months that the Silicon Valley couple has made splashy appearances in Trump’s orbit. In the fall, they attended two other White House suppers and went to Trump’s revamped Kennedy Center Honors, dining later that evening with one of the honorees, actor Sylvester Stallone. But nothing has more loudly announced their arrival as Trump-friendly figures than their decision to become megadonors: giving $50 million to Leading the Future, a bipartisan super PAC focused on combating state-level AI regulation, and $25 million to MAGA Inc., a Trump super PAC.

item.title: Major Crypto Exchanges Are Racing to Offer U.S. Stocks
item.description:
Crypto Exchanges Want to Trade U.S. Stocks Everywhere
Some of the world’s biggest crypto exchanges are racing to let their customers trade crypto tokens that seek to track U.S. stocks, creating a parallel market that’s beyond the reach of U.S. regulators. Binance is exploring reintroducing stock tokens on its exchange after having removed them in 2021, according to a person familiar with the plan. OKX, another major global platform, is also considering offering tokenized stocks, according to its global managing partner and chief marketing officer, Haider Rafique. Exchanges including Kraken and Bitget and decentralized platforms like Jupiter are already gaining traction with their stock token offerings.
Jan 23, 2026

Exclusive

Crypto Exchanges Want to Trade U.S. Stocks Everywhere

By Yueqi Yang

Some of the world’s biggest crypto exchanges are racing to let their customers trade crypto tokens that seek to track U.S. stocks, creating a parallel market that’s beyond the reach of U.S. regulators.

Binance is exploring reintroducing stock tokens on its exchange after having removed them in 2021, according to a person familiar with the plan. OKX, another major global platform, is also considering offering tokenized stocks, according to its global managing partner and chief marketing officer, Haider Rafique. Exchanges including Kraken and Bitget and decentralized platforms like Jupiter are already gaining traction with their stock token offerings.

Read the full article

The Takeaway

  • Overseas crypto exchanges offer U.S. stock tokens, bypassing U.S. regulations.
  • Tokenized stock market value reached $915 million, up 19% monthly.
  • NYSE and Nasdaq plan to offer stock tokens, seeking regulatory approval.

item.title: I Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.
item.description:
How 13 AI agents reviewing in parallel caught a critical bug I would have otherwise missed  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Source Code

I Stopped Reading Code. My Code Reviews Got Better.

How 13 AI agents reviewing in parallel caught a critical bug I would have otherwise missed

by Kieran Klaassen

Was this newsletter forwarded to you? Sign up to get it in your inbox.

The bug report was deceptively simple: A user noticed that their email signature formatting was off in Cora, our AI-powered email assistant. I asked Claude Code to investigate and fix it. By morning, the fix had touched 27 files, and more than 1,000 lines of code had changed. I didn’t write any of them.

A year ago, I would have spent my afternoon reading that code. Line by line, file by file, squinting at the migration that moved email_signature from one database table to another, Ctrl+F-ing for every instance of our feature flags.

This time, I spent 15 minutes making decisions, and the code shipped without a single bug.

Before AI, code review meant reading every line a teammate wrote. You checked for typos, logic errors, and style inconsistencies, the way an editor reviews a manuscript. Now my code reviews no longer involve reading code. And I’ve gotten better at catching problems because of it.

This is code review done the compound engineering way: Agents review in parallel, findings become decisions, and every correction teaches the system what to catch next time. The signature fix that touched 27 files? Thirteen specialized AI reviewers examined it simultaneously while I made dinner.

I’ll show you how I set it up, how it caught a critical bug I would have missed, and how you can start—even without custom tooling.

The death of manual code review

Reading code, even briefly, gave me a sense of the shape of things. I could feel when the codebase was getting too complicated. By letting go of manual review, I worried that I’d lose that clarity, and the architecture would wander off without me.

But I realized, too, that manual code reviews were no longer sustainable. When a developer writes 200 lines, their manager might spend 20 to 40 minutes reading it. The ratio of time spent writing code to reviewing it holds at 5:1 or 10:1—I can sit down with a cup of coffee, and the coffee will still be warm by the time I finish. AI has broken that ratio. The time it takes to generate code has collapsed, but the time it takes for a human to review code hasn’t. Something had to give.

The shift from manual review happened slowly. When Claude Code enacted a set of fixes, I’d ask it questions, then read the diff (the line-by-line comparison showing what had changed). When I was satisfied, I’d hold my breath and merge the changes into the main codebase.

Nothing broke. The code was fine. It turned out that asking Claude to explain its reasoning—what it changed, why, and what might break—caught more than my tired eyes scrolling through diffs.

After a while, that close read turned into a quick skim. The skim turned into a glance. Eventually I found that by the time I had asked my questions, I’d already hit “merge.”

I still understood how good the code was—that clarity just came in a different way. Instead of feeling the shape of the code by reading it, I felt it by interrogating Claude Code:

  1. “Walk me through what you changed and why.”
  2. “What assumptions did you make?”
  3. “What would break this?”
  4. “Why did you ignore the feedback from kieran-reviewer?”

That last one needs explaining. kieran-reviewer is an AI agent I built—a specialized reviewer trained on my code preferences. It knows, for instance, that I prefer simple queries over complex queries and clear code over clever code. It’s one of 13 reviewers that examine every pull request before I see it.

Why so many agents? No single reviewer, human or AI, catches everything in a 27-file change. A security expert spots authentication gaps but misses database issues. A performance specialist catches slow queries but ignores style drift. I needed specialists working in parallel, each focused on what they’re good at. Together, they catch what I might miss from a manual review.

Write at the speed of thought

That gap between your brain and your fingers kills momentum. Monologue lets you speak naturally and get perfect text 3x faster, and your tone, vocabulary, and style is kept intact. It auto-learns proper nouns, handles multilingual code-switching mid-sentence, and edits for accuracy. Free 1,000 words to start.

Download Monologue for Mac
Want to sponsor Every? Click here.

Using the compound engineering plugin

My system for code review is rolled up into the compound engineering plugin. It’s a set of files in your codebase that extend what Claude Code can do. Here’s how it works.

Slash commands are shortcuts you type in the terminal—like /workflows:review or /workflows:plan—that trigger workflows. Each workflow is a markdown file with instructions for what Claude should do when you invoke it.

Agents are specialized AI workers, each defined in its own markdown file with a persona and focus area.

For the email signature fix, I ran a single command: /workflows:review, which spun up every agent on its list at once:

  1. kieran-rails-reviewer checks my personal style preferences
  2. code-simplicity-reviewer hunts for over-engineering
  3. data-integrity-guardian validates database changes during migrations (when the structure of your database changes)
  4. security-sentinel checks for authentication bypasses
  5. Plus nine more, each with a specific focus

Ten minutes later, they returned with findings ranked by priority.

From findings to decisions

The agents produce findings. But a list of issues isn’t useful—I need to know what to do about them. So I run the next command: /triage

Triage takes all 13 reviewers’ findings, ranks them by severity, and walks me through each one. It presents every finding in the same way: Here’s the problem, here’s why it matters, now what do you want to do?


I can accept the recommendation (and the system creates a task to fix it), skip it (it’s not worth addressing), or provide specific instructions.

The signature fix surfaced three findings. The first was critical: The code had moved where we store a user setting, but one file still looked for it in the old location. If I’d shipped this, every user who tried to generate a draft response would have hit an error. The fix itself is trivial—point the code at the new location—but I never would have caught it scrolling through diffs.

The second was cleanup. A chunk of unused code, left over from an earlier approach. It wasn’t broken, but it was confusing. On the chance that someone did read the code in the future, they would wonder what it was for. I approved this change too.

The third was a nitpick—a minor redundancy, technically true but harmless. I skipped it. I’ll clean it up next time I’m in that file.

I got three findings and made three decisions in less than two minutes.

The critical finding alone justified the review. I never would have caught a mismatched reference on line 31 while scrolling through 1,000 lines at 6 p.m. The agents caught it in seconds.

The fix is never the last fix

The signature fix should have been simple. I’d make one change and be done. But sometimes when you fix a piece of code, you end up breaking another. This is just as true with human developers as with coding agents.

In our case, the first version fixed the signature formatting in Gmail, but it broke the plain text version of emails. Some email apps don’t display styled text, and now those users saw raw formatting codes instead of readable text.

So we fixed that. But the fix for plain text created extra blank lines for users who didn’t have signatures at all.

So I fixed that too. Then we discovered that when you reply to a heavily-styled marketing email, our formatting rules were leaking into the quoted text. Users saw gibberish like #outlook a { padding: 0; } in their message body.

I fixed that. Next we found that Cora was now appending your email signature after each suggested draft of an email, instead of just once at the very end. If you generated three options, you’d get three signatures. Which called for another fix.

Ten versions of the code. Four bugs we introduced while fixing the original. Hence the 27 files and thousand lines of code. Again, this is a normal part of any development process, human or AI. The difference is that here, we can codify our learnings to make sure we don’t make the same mistake next time.

The 50/50 rule

I spent 15 minutes fixing those bugs. Then I spent another 15 minutes making sure I’d never see them again.

After the signature mess, we created a document called refactor-email-content-rendering.md. It lives in our codebase, and it captures everything we learned:

  1. A chart showing every combination of user settings and what should happen in each case, so there would be no more guessing.
  2. A simple rule about which part of the system handles formatting: “The background process sends styled text. The Gmail connector never converts formats.”
  3. The exact format Gmail expects for signatures, pulled from actual emails we tested—not what we assumed, but what we verified.

That document is now part of the project. The next time anyone touches email rendering—whether that’s me, a teammate, or Claude—the AI reads it first.

In my first weeks using this workflow, Claude presented me with approaches that weren’t necessarily wrong, but didn’t reflect my preferences. What I consider “over-engineered,” another engineer might call “robust.” What I see as a missed pattern, someone else might not use at all. Three months and 50-plus reviews in, Claude’s plans largely reflect how I’d approach problems myself.

Better AI models make everyone’s output better. But your system gets better because you’re accumulating your own team’s knowledge. Your agents learn your preferences, and your review process reveals your blind spots. That’s where compounding happens.

So follow the 50/50 rule: Spend half your time reviewing output, half ensuring the lesson sticks.

Rethink reviews

Most engineers assume they need to read everything. That assumption made sense when humans wrote all the code. But it doesn’t anymore.

I shipped the email signature fix without reading most of the code. I reviewed findings and made decisions. I looked at screenshots in Gmail. But did I read the implementation details of how we extract email content? No. Did I trace through how the database change handles edge cases? No.

Yet the feature works. Users get properly formatted signatures. The tests—checks I write alongside every feature to verify the code behaves correctly—all pass. The screenshots look right. It took some time to let go of manual code reviews, but the results speak for themselves.

The trade I’ve made is that I won’t read every line, but a part of the time I would spend reading code now goes toward making the system smarter. I’m adding test cases for marketing emails stuffed with weird formatting. I’m capturing “when you change where data lives, check every file that reads it” as a rule the agents enforce automatically. This way, the next person who touches this code—human or AI—doesn’t repeat my mistakes.

If you don’t have the compound engineering plugin yet, start with three questions. Before you approve any AI-generated output—code, documents, or strategy decks—ask the AI:

  1. What was the hardest decision you made here?
  2. What alternatives did you reject, and why?
  3. What are you least confident about?

That conversation, which takes two minutes, surfaces what a 30-minute unfocused manual check would have missed. The AI knows where the tricky parts are. It just doesn’t volunteer them unless you ask.

Then apply the 50/50 rule. Spend half of your time fixing the immediate problem and half documenting it, making sure the problem never comes back.

The 27 files involved in rendering an email signature are waiting for the next feature. I’m still not going to read them all. But when I’m done, the system will know more than it did when I started.

Kieran Klaassen is the general manager of Cora, Every’s email product. Follow him on X at @kieranklaassen or on LinkedIn.

To read more essays like this, subscribe to Every, and follow us on X at @every and on LinkedIn.

item.title: The math on AI agents doesn’t add up
item.description:
PLUS: What hallucinations reveal about the future of automation.

View in browser  |  Update preferences 

■ In this week’s Backchannel: A research paper suggests AI agents are mathematically doomed to fail. The industry doesn’t agree.

 

Agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time

The big AI companies promised us that 2025 would be “the year of the AI agents.” It turned out to be the year of talking about AI agents, and kicking the can for that transformational moment to 2026 or maybe later. But what if the answer to the question “When will our lives be fully automated by generative AI robots that perform our tasks for us and basically run the world?” is, like that New Yorker cartoon, “How about never?”

That was basically the message of a paper published without much fanfare some months ago, smack in the middle of the overhyped year of “agentic AI.” Entitled “Hallucination Stations: On Some Basic Limitations of Transformer-Based Language Models,” it purports to mathematically show that “LLMs are incapable of carrying out computational and agentic tasks beyond a certain complexity.” Though the science is beyond me, the authors—a former SAP CTO who studied AI under one of the field’s founding intellects, John McCarthy; and his teenage prodigy son—punctured the vision of agentic paradise with the certainty of mathematics. Even reasoning models that go beyond the pure word-prediction process of LLMs, they say, won’t fix the problem.

“There is no way they can be reliable,” Vishal Sikka, the dad, tells me. After a career that, in addition to SAP, included a stint as Infosys CEO and an Oracle board member, he currently heads an AI services startup called Vianai. “So we should forget about AI agents running nuclear power plants?” I ask. “Exactly,” he says. Maybe you can get it to file some papers or something to save time, but you might have to resign yourself to some mistakes.

The AI industry begs to differ. For one thing, a big success in agent AI has been coding, which took off last year. Just this week at Davos, Google’s Nobel-winning head of AI, Demis Hassabis, reported breakthroughs in minimizing hallucinations, and hyperscalers and startups alike are pushing the agent narrative. Now they have some backup. A startup called Harmonic is reporting a breakthrough in AI coding that also hinges on mathematics—and tops benchmarks on reliability.

Harmonic, which was cofounded by Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev and Tudor Achim, a Stanford-trained mathematician, claims this recent improvement to its product called Aristotle (no hubris there!) is an indication that there are ways to guarantee the trustworthiness of AI systems. “Are we doomed to be in a world where AI just generates slop and humans can't really check it? That would be a crazy world,” says Achim. Harmonic’s solution is to use formal methods of mathematical reasoning to verify an LLM’s output. Specifically, it encodes outputs in the Lean programming language, which is known for its ability to verify the coding. To be sure, Harmonic’s focus to date has been narrow—its key mission is the pursuit of “mathematical superintelligence,” and coding is a somewhat organic extension. Things like history essays—which can’t be mathematically verified—are beyond its boundaries. For now.

Nonetheless, Achim doesn’t seem to think that reliable agentic behavior is as much an issue as some critics believe. “I would say that most models at this point have the level of pure intelligence required to reason through booking a travel itinerary,” he says.

Both sides are right—or maybe even on the same side. On one hand, everyone agrees that hallucinations will continue to be a vexing reality. In a paper published last September, OpenAI scientists wrote, “Despite significant progress, hallucinations continue to plague the field, and are still present in the latest models.” They proved that unhappy claim by asking three models, including ChatGPT, to provide the title of the lead author’s dissertation. All three made up fake titles and all misreported the year of publication. In a blog about the paper, OpenAI glumly stated that in AI models, “accuracy will never reach 100 percent.”

Right now, those inaccuracies are serious enough to discourage the wide adoption of agents in the corporate world. “The value has not been delivered,” says Himanshu Tyagi, cofounder of an open source AI company called Sentient. He points out that dealing with hallucinations can disrupt an entire work flow, negating much of the value of an agent.

Yet the big AI powers and many startups believe these inaccuracies can be dealt with. The key to coexisting with hallucinations, they say, is creating guardrails that filter out the imaginative bullshit that LLMs love to produce. Even Sikka thinks that this is a probable outcome. “Our paper is saying that a pure LLM has this inherent limitation—but at the same time it is true that you can build components around LLMs that overcome those limitations,” he says.

Achim, the mathematical verification guy, agrees that hallucinations will always be around—but considers this a feature, not a bug. “I think hallucinations are intrinsic to LLMs and also necessary for going beyond human intelligence,” he says. “The way that systems learn is by hallucinating something. It’s often wrong, but sometimes it's something that no human has ever thought before.”

The bottom line is that like generative AI itself, agentic AI is both impossible and inevitable at the same time. There may not be a specific annum that will be looked back upon as “the year of the agent.” But hallucinations or not, every year from now on is going to be “the year of more agents,” as the delta between guardrails and hallucinations narrows. The industry has too much at stake not to make this happen. The tasks that agents perform will always require some degree of verification—and of course people will get sloppy and we’ll suffer small and large disasters—but eventually agents will match or surpass the reliability of human beings, while being faster and cheaper.

At that point, some bigger questions arise. One person I contacted to discuss the hallucination paper was computer pioneer Alan Kay, who is friendly with Sikka. His view is that “their argument was posed well enough to get comments from real computational theorists.” (A statement reminiscent of his 1984 take on the Macintosh as “the first personal computer good enough to be criticized.”) But ultimately, he says, the mathematical question is beside the point. Instead, he suggests people consider the issue in light of Marshall McLuhan’s famous “Medium is the message” dictum. “Don’t ask whether something is good or bad, right or wrong,” he paraphrases. “Find out what is going on.”

Here’s what’s going on: We may well be on the cusp of a massive automation of human cognitive activity. It’s an open question whether this will improve the quality of our work and our lives. I suspect that the ultimate assessment of that will not be mathematically verifiable.

Time Travel

I was heartened that Tudor Achim spoke well of hallucinations, because two years ago I wrote “In Defense of AI Hallucinations,” a piece that embraced the possibility that AI would never rid itself of its troublesome inaccuracies. Like Achim, I celebrated the creative spirit of AI confabulation. But I also conjectured that as long as chatbots got stuff wrong, we wouldn’t let them take over the world. I’m not so sure about the last part anymore.

Santosh Vempala, a computer science professor at Georgia Tech, has also studied hallucinations. “A language model is just a probabilistic model of the world,” he says, not a truthful mirror of reality. Vempala explains that an LLM’s answer strives for a general calibration with the real world—as represented in its training data—which is “a weak version of accuracy.” His research, published with OpenAI’s Adam Kalai, found that hallucinations are unavoidable for facts that can’t be verified using the information in a model’s training data.

That’s the science/math of AI hallucinations, but they’re also notable for the experience they can elicit in humans. At times, these generative fabrications can seem more plausible than actual facts, which are often astonishingly bizarre and unsatisfying. How often do you hear something described as so strange that no screenwriter would dare script it in a movie? These days, all the time! Hallucinations can seduce us by appearing to ground us to a world less jarring than the actual one we live in. What’s more, I find it telling to note just which details the bots tend to concoct. In their desperate attempt to fill in the blanks of a satisfying narrative, they gravitate toward the most statistically likely version of reality as represented in their internet-scale training data, which can be a truth in itself. I liken it to a fiction writer penning a novel inspired by real events. A good author will veer from what actually happened to an imagined scenario that reveals a deeper truth, striving to create something more real than reality.

Ask Me One Question

Alexandra asks, “How do tech journalists stay curious without getting cynical?"

Thanks for the question, Alexandra. It’s helpful that you gave a clue as to what you meant by sharing that you are recovering from tech burnout and are worried about returning to that world “without falling back into the toxic parts.” So what you are saying is that some of the unattractive aspects of techland—selfish oligarchs, enshittified products, and the pursuit of progress without sufficient regard for what benefits society—can nullify what’s truly exciting about the field.

I can’t speak for all tech journalists, but what keeps me from being cynical is a perpetual fascination with the technology itself and the people who lend their creativity and acumen to building breakthrough products and making cutting-edge discoveries. For instance, I found that writing the backstory of the invention of AI transformers was inspiring, fun, and instructive.

And if some of those people turn to the dark side? Hey, that’s interesting too. Instead of fomenting cynicism, bad behavior on the part of powerful tech people calls for the scrutiny that journalists can and should exercise. Identifying the flaws in our world doesn’t make us cynical—beaming sunshine in dark corners is actually a hopeful act, urging people to do better. Even if fanboys rip us on social media for our work.

Quote of the Week

“[AI] may go too fast for society … Should you do it all at once? No. You will have civil unrest. So phase it in.”

—JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, speaking at Davos in favor of hitting the brakes on AI.

What did you think about today's newsletter? Let me know by emailing me at backchannel@wired.com

  • We Are Witnessing the Self-Immolation of a Superpower With Donald Trump’s actions in Greenland, Minneapolis, and Venezuela, a foreign enemy could not invent a better chain of events to wreck the standing of the United States.
  • Chinese EV Batteries Are Eating the World China’s lithium batteries aren’t always “made in China.” Companies like BYD and CATL are building factories on nearly every continent.
  • Your First Humanoid Robot Coworker Will Probably Be Chinese Explosive acceleration, limited dexterity, eyes in the back of its head. What could possibly go wrong?

item.title: AI Frontiers on TechCrunch
item.description:

AI Frontiers on Hacker News
January 23, 2026
I was banned from Claude for scaffolding a Claude.md file?
• Article: https://hugodaniel.com/posts/claude-code-banned-me/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46723384
• Score: 616
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • A developer using Anthropic's Claude AI for personal coding projects faced an account ban after automating prompts resembling system instructions, triggering moderation heuristics. The ban occurred without warning or explanation, highlighting the opaque nature of AI moderation systems.
  • • The developer's project involved running two Claude instances to iterate on scaffolding tools, but the process was flagged as a violation, possibly due to prompt injection concerns. The incident underscores challenges in using AI tools for advanced automation.
  • • Following the ban, the developer received a refund but no communication or support from Anthropic. The experience raises concerns about AI safety protocols prioritizing extreme caution over user engagement and accuracy.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • **Service Reliability and Customer Support**: Many commenters shared frustrations with Anthropic's Claude service becoming unreliable, with issues such as flakiness, failed prompts, and unresponsiveness. A recurring theme was the lack of adequate customer support, which often consists of automated responses or an AI bot, with human escalation being rare or ineffective.
  • • **Account Bans and Lack of Transparency**: Several users reported being banned from Claude without clear explanations or recourse, sometimes after seemingly innocuous actions like using a VPN or submitting certain prompts. The lack of transparency in the banning process and appeals system was widely criticized.
  • • **Prompt Injection and Automation Concerns**: The discussion included speculation about bans being triggered by activities perceived as prompt injection or automation misuse, such as using Claude to modify its own behavior or scaffolding projects.
  • • **Alternatives to Claude**: Commenters debated other LLMs like ChatGPT, Gemini, and open-source models such as GLM, Mistral, and locally hosted solutions. Some expressed preference for open-source models to avoid corporate control and censorship.
  • • **Ethical and Systemic Issues**: The conversation touched on broader concerns about corporate control over AI tools, lack of accountability, and the implications of centralized AI systems on users' freedom and livelihoods.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: There was widespread consensus that Anthropic's customer support and transparency need significant improvement. Many commenters agreed that the lack of human support and unclear banning policies create a poor user experience.
  • • **Disagreement**: Opinions varied on the viability of alternatives to Claude. Some praised open-source models for independence, while others argued they lag behind proprietary models in quality and reliability. There was also debate over whether Anthropic's bans were justified or overly harsh.
  • • **Mixed Sentiments on AI Moderation**: While some supported strict moderation for safety, others criticized the over-reliance on automated systems and the lack of human oversight.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment was predominantly negative, with many users expressing frustration, disappointment, and distrust toward Anthropic's handling of Claude's reliability and support issues. Some commenters were optimistic about alternatives, while others were skeptical of their capabilities.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Contributions**:
  • • **Local Models as a Solution**: Several commenters advocated for running local LLMs to avoid corporate restrictions and bans, emphasizing the importance of decentralization in AI.
  • • **Anthropic's Strategic Risk**: One commenter highlighted the potential damage to Anthropic's reputation if it doesn't trust its own AI for customer support, questioning why corporate clients should rely on Claude.
  • • **Broader Implications**: Commenters discussed the risks of centralized AI tools potentially barring users from industries or workflows, likening it to monopolistic control.
  • 5. **Recurring Issues**:
  • • **Token Usage and Costs**: Users reported dissatisfaction with unclear token limits and pricing, particularly for high-cost plans like Claude Max.
  • • **Automation and Prompt Injection**: Many commenters speculated that Anthropic's automated systems flagged benign actions as malicious, leading to bans.
  • • **Calls for Regulation**: Some commenters advocated for legal frameworks to prevent arbitrary bans and ensure accountability in AI services.
  • 6. **Notable Comments**:
  • • A commenter highlighted the chilling effect of Anthropic's banning practices on developers, discouraging investment in Claude-specific tools.
  • • Another user suggested prompt injection techniques could be exploited maliciously to ban organizations from AI tools.
  • • Discussions on open-source models like Mistral and GLM provided valuable insights into alternatives to proprietary LLMs.
  • In summary, the discussion underscored dissatisfaction with Anthropic's service reliability, customer support, and banning policies, while exploring alternatives and raising broader concerns about corporate control in AI.
Proton Spam and the AI Consent Problem
• Article: https://dbushell.com/2026/01/22/proton-spam/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46729368
• Score: 290
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Proton sent an email promoting its AI feature, Lumo, to a user who had explicitly opted out of Lumo-related communications, raising concerns about privacy and consent. The email was labeled as part of the "Proton for Business" newsletter, which the user disputes as misleading.
  • • The incident highlights broader issues within the AI industry, where companies often disregard user preferences and consent, pushing AI into products and services without explicit approval. This trend is criticized for undermining trust and violating ethical standards.
  • • The user calls out Proton's handling of the situation, emphasizing the growing problem of non-consent in tech, especially within the AI sector, which frequently sidesteps privacy laws and user autonomy.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics of Discussion**:
  • • **Proton's Marketing Practices**: Many commenters criticized Proton's intrusive marketing emails, particularly around their AI product "Lumo." Users expressed frustration over receiving promotional emails despite opting out, with some suggesting this behavior undermines trust in the company.
  • • **AI and Consent**: The broader issue of AI being forcefully integrated into products and services without user consent was heavily discussed. Commenters noted that AI marketing often disregards user preferences, reflecting a trend of non-consensual implementation across the tech industry.
  • • **Comparison to Competitors**: Several commenters highlighted their dissatisfaction with Proton's overall suite of products, including email and VPN services, and shared positive experiences with alternatives like Fastmail and Tutanota.
  • • **Ethics and Accountability in Tech**: Commenters debated the ethical implications of marketing practices and the lack of consumer protection in the tech industry, pointing out that GDPR enforcement is limited outside of Europe.
  • • **Broader Tech Industry Trends**: Some commenters linked Proton's behavior to a larger trend of "enshittification," where companies prioritize profit over user experience and trust as they scale.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • **Agreement**: Many commenters agreed that Proton's marketing practices, particularly around AI, are problematic and erode trust. There was consensus that non-consensual marketing emails are unethical and frustrating.
  • • **Disagreement**: While most criticized Proton, a few defended the company, arguing that the issue might stem from technical errors or misclassification rather than malice. Others felt the complaints were exaggerated and suggested unsubscribing was a simple solution.
  • • **AI-Specific Criticism**: Some commenters believed the issue is specific to AI hype and marketing, while others argued this behavior is typical of marketing teams in general, regardless of the product being promoted.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion was largely negative, with commenters expressing dissatisfaction with Proton's marketing practices and broader trends in the tech industry. Frustration and distrust were common sentiments, especially regarding AI-related marketing and lack of respect for user preferences.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters shared personal experiences with Proton and other companies, highlighting issues like slow product development, poor customer support, and misleading marketing practices.
  • • A commenter provided a detailed perspective on how internal conflicts between support and marketing teams might lead to such incidents, offering insight into corporate dynamics.
  • • Comparisons to competitors like Fastmail and Tutanota revealed that users prioritize simplicity, reliability, and trust in their choice of email providers.
  • 5. **Key Takeaways**:
  • • Proton's marketing practices, particularly around AI, have led to significant user frustration and loss of trust.
  • • The tech industry's disregard for user consent in marketing and product integration is a widespread issue, with AI being a focal point.
  • • Many users are considering or have already switched to competitors due to dissatisfaction with Proton's products and practices.
  • • Ethical concerns and lack of accountability in tech marketing were recurring themes in the discussion.
Meet the Alaska Student Arrested for Eating an AI Art Exhibit
• Article: https://www.thenation.com/article/society/alaska-student-arrested-eating-ai-art-exhibit/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46719465
• Score: 97
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • University of Alaska Fairbanks student Graham Granger protested AI-generated art by tearing and eating pieces of an exhibit, criticizing AI for undermining the creative process and relying on other artists' work without consent.
  • • Granger views AI as a valuable tool but believes it has no place in art, arguing that the lack of human effort and inability to process criticism devalues the art form and harms genuine artists.
  • • The incident, initially intended to spark campus-wide discussion, gained international attention, with Granger standing by his actions despite facing legal consequences.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topic**: The discussion revolves around an incident where an individual ate an AI-generated art exhibit as a form of protest, sparking debates about the validity of AI art, artistic expression, and the ethics of such protests.
  • 2. **Themes and Points of Discussion**:
  • • **Protest and Impact**: Some commenters debated the effectiveness of the protest, with comparisons made to other acts of defiance, such as slashing oil truck tires. Opinions varied on whether targeting AI art was the right approach, with suggestions that companies like OpenAI or MidJourney might be more appropriate targets.
  • • **AI Art as a Medium**: There was significant discussion about the artistic value of AI-generated works. Some criticized AI art as low-effort and lacking in value compared to traditional art, while others acknowledged its potential to explore new creative ideas, such as "AI psychosis" and identity formation.
  • • **Artistic Impulses**: Several commenters reflected on the impulsive nature of the act, with some defending impulsivity as part of artistic expression and others dismissing it as misguided or unnecessary.
  • • **Legal and Ethical Considerations**: The conversation touched on the legal consequences of the protest, with discussions about pressing charges and the role of victims in prosecution. Some questioned the necessity of pursuing legal action for such a minor incident.
  • • **Cultural Context**: Comparisons were made to historical protests against new technologies in art, such as the backlash against mass-produced color printers. This led to broader reflections on how society values art and the artist's role in its creation.
  • 3. **Disagreements**:
  • • **Value of AI Art**: Opinions were divided on whether AI-generated art should be considered legitimate. Critics dismissed it as lacking artistic merit, while others argued that it is a valid medium deserving of exploration.
  • • **Protest Justification**: Some supported the protest as a form of direct action, while others saw it as counterproductive or ineffective in achieving meaningful change.
  • • **Sentiment Toward AI**: While some commenters expressed frustration and negativity toward AI's role in art, others called for a more informed understanding of the technology and its potential.
  • 4. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion was mixed, with a blend of humor, skepticism, and critical analysis. While some commenters expressed frustration with AI art and the protest, others took a more lighthearted or philosophical approach to the topic.
  • 5. **Notable Insights**:
  • • The act of eating the AI art exhibit was compared to performance art and other provocative artistic gestures, such as the infamous banana at Art Basel.
  • • Commenters highlighted the growing tension between traditional and AI-driven artistic practices, reflecting broader societal debates about technology and creativity.
  • • Some pointed out the media's role in sensationalizing such incidents and fostering polarized opinions about AI.
  • 6. **Humorous Contributions**:
  • • Several commenters added humor to the discussion, with jokes about eating AI art and its "nutritional value" or comparing it to other absurd artistic protests.
  • 7. **Calls for Nuance**:
  • • A few commenters emphasized the need for a deeper understanding of AI tools and their capabilities, urging critics to move beyond surface-level judgments.
Show HN: I've been using AI to analyze every supplement on the market
• Article: https://pillser.com/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46719423
• Score: 77
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Technical Insights on AI and Supplements**: The discussion includes comments about using AI to analyze and evaluate supplements. A commenter shared their journey of building internal evaluations to assess LLMs' performance, noting significant improvements in newer models like Opus 4.5. Others praised the use of AI but highlighted limitations, such as the inability to physically test products for ingredient accuracy or contamination. The project founder expressed aspirations to expand into lab testing and high-quality supplement production.
  • 2. **Regulatory Concerns**: Multiple commenters discussed the lack of oversight in the U.S. supplement industry, likening it to a "wild west." Issues like labeling inaccuracies and ingredient purity were raised, with suggestions that supplements should be regulated similarly to food. International comparisons (e.g., Australia) and niche concerns like pet food regulations were also mentioned.
  • 3. **Monetization Strategies**: Monetization was a recurring topic. The founder shared plans to rely on affiliate revenue rather than ads, citing affiliate commissions of 5-10%. Commenters encouraged exploring alternative models, referencing Examine.com as an example. Some raised concerns about legal challenges from companies demanding product removal, with the founder emphasizing transparency and resilience against such threats.
  • 4. **Data Accuracy and Bugs**: Several comments identified data errors and site bugs, such as incorrect pricing and search issues. The founder acknowledged these issues and shared plans to prioritize fixes and improve data evaluations, especially for powdered supplements. They also expressed appreciation for feedback and the importance of building a community for ongoing improvement.
  • 5. **Sentiment Toward Supplements**: Commenters expressed mixed views on supplements. While some highlighted their importance for hard-to-get nutrients like Vitamin K2 and magnesium, others warned about risks like toxicity and emphasized eating real food. The founder agreed that many supplement sales are driven by marketing rather than science, reinforcing their goal to make the process more evidence-based.
  • 6. **Community Engagement**: The founder actively engaged with commenters, seeking feedback on prioritizing data, addressing errors, and discussing future directions. They expressed enthusiasm for building a community to guide the project’s development and shared contact information for further collaboration.
  • 7. **Legal and Market Challenges**: Concerns about legal threats from supplement companies were discussed, with commenters advising against removing products under pressure. The founder noted their improved ability to handle such challenges and highlighted the vast market size of supplements, aiming to carve a niche by offering comprehensive data and comparisons.
  • 8. **Unique Features and Suggestions**: Commenters appreciated innovative features like AI responses triggered by adding a “?” to searches. Suggestions included expanding the dataset to cover the EU market and refining search functionality to avoid misleading results.
  • Overall, the discussion was constructive, with a mix of technical insights, critiques, and suggestions for improvement. Sentiment ranged from optimism about the project's potential to skepticism about AI's role in the supplement industry. The founder demonstrated openness to feedback and a clear vision for future growth.
Why I don't have fun with Claude Code
• Article: https://brennan.io/2026/01/23/claude-code/
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730671
• Score: 72
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • AI coding tools like Claude Code and Codex are revolutionizing software development by automating tasks, allowing users to quickly create features or projects. However, not all developers embrace this shift, as some value the process of coding and learning over just the end result.
  • • For product-focused developers, these tools are transformative, enabling faster iterations and results by acting as "managers" of AI systems. But for others, like the author, the joy lies in understanding and building systems, which AI automation can diminish.
  • • The discussion highlights the importance of aligning tools with personal goals. Tasks where the process matters, such as learning or skill-building, may require a hands-on approach, while AI tools can be reserved for automating less valued, repetitive tasks.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **General Sentiment and Themes**:
  • • The discussion revolves around the use of AI coding agents, such as Claude Code, and their impact on software development.
  • • Opinions are split between those who view AI tools as valuable assistants that enhance productivity and those who express concern about their implications for craftsmanship and understanding in coding.
  • • The overall sentiment is mixed, with many commenters acknowledging the utility of AI tools while expressing varying levels of skepticism or enthusiasm.
  • 2. **Key Points of Agreement**:
  • • AI tools are effective for automating repetitive or tedious tasks, such as refactoring, improving test coverage, or handling boilerplate code.
  • • Many commenters value AI tools for augmenting their coding process, enabling faster iterations, exploring alternatives, and providing insights on unfamiliar concepts.
  • • There is consensus that AI tools are helpful for personal projects, learning, and speeding up development workflows, but their reliability and accuracy require careful human oversight.
  • 3. **Key Points of Disagreement**:
  • • Some commenters argue that reliance on AI tools diminishes the value of understanding and creating software, while others counter that these tools are merely a means to save time and focus on higher-level problem-solving.
  • • A few express concerns about AI-generated code introducing subtle bugs and liabilities, leading to frustration and increased debugging efforts.
  • • There is debate over whether using AI tools trivializes the craft of coding or simply shifts focus to different aspects of software development.
  • 4. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Several commenters liken the use of AI tools to the adoption of power tools in craftsmanship, emphasizing that the goals of automation and manual creation are not necessarily opposed.
  • • Some view AI coding agents as "coding buddies" that enhance learning and experimentation, while others compare them to tools that democratize programming by lowering barriers to entry.
  • • A recurring theme is the trade-off between time savings and maintaining deep engagement with the code, with some commenters advocating for balancing both aspects.
  • 5. **Concerns About Industry Impact**:
  • • A few commenters raise concerns about AI tools potentially reducing the need for developers or lowering the skill level required for software changes, leading to job insecurity.
  • • There is anxiety about the broader implications of AI tools on the software development profession, with some fearing a shift toward commoditization or factory-level production.
  • 6. **Notable Analogies and Comparisons**:
  • • AI coding tools are compared to other technologies that automate tasks people don’t value doing, such as cars for transportation or Python for simplifying programming.
  • • The debate is likened to discussions in other creative domains, such as music, where automation and craftsmanship coexist but sometimes lead to polarized opinions.
  • 7. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • While many commenters appreciate the practical benefits of AI tools, such as saving time and enabling faster iterations, there is a strong undercurrent of concern about losing the creative and intellectual engagement that comes with manual coding.
  • • The discussion reflects a balance between pragmatism and idealism, with individuals expressing diverse perspectives based on their personal experiences and values.
White House defends sharing AI image showing arrested woman crying
• Article: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/ce9yydgmzdvt
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46731865
• Score: 71
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Experts have identified AI editing in an image shared by the White House, altering the expression of a woman arrested during a protest in Minnesota. The manipulated image shows her crying, contrasting with the original where she appeared expressionless.
  • • Hany Farid, a computer science professor, criticized the use of AI-generated content by the White House, calling it "deceptive" and harmful to public trust in official communications.
  • • The White House defended its actions via a post by deputy communications director Kaelan Dorr, emphasizing law enforcement and dismissing concerns over the manipulated image.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics and Themes**:
  • • The discussion centers around the White House's use of an AI-generated image of a crying woman and broader implications of government manipulation through deepfakes and propaganda.
  • • Commenters highlight the erosion of trust in the government, particularly in the context of deceptive practices like altering images and spreading misinformation.
  • • The conversation also touches on Trump-era tactics, including the normalization of media manipulation, human rights concerns, and the prioritization of "owning the libs" over governance.
  • 2. **Significant Agreements and Disagreements**:
  • • Many commenters agree that the use of AI to doctor images is unethical and undermines trust in government communications.
  • • There is consensus that such behavior reflects a broader trend of deception and propaganda, with commenters lamenting the lack of accountability.
  • • Some debate whether the misleading article title contributed to misunderstandings about the issue, with one commenter questioning how the title could be interpreted differently.
  • 3. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The sentiment of the discussion is overwhelmingly negative, with commenters expressing frustration, anger, and disbelief at the government’s actions.
  • • There is widespread concern about the implications of deepfake technology being used by officials and the normalization of deceptive practices in politics and media.
  • 4. **Unique Insights and Valuable Contributions**:
  • • One commenter points out the irony of a subset of Americans supporting government overreach despite previously opposing it, highlighting a shift in political dynamics.
  • • Another commenter links the issue to broader human rights concerns, referencing the March CECOT deportations and their lack of media coverage.
  • • Several comments critique the media’s role in legitimizing deceptive practices and failing to counter propaganda effectively.
  • 5. **Additional Observations**:
  • • The use of memes and deepfakes is seen as a deliberate strategy to distract from serious issues, such as allegations of pedophilia and corruption.
  • • Commenters emphasize the importance of holding the government accountable for lying to the public and manipulating information, suggesting that these practices undermine democracy.
  • • There is a recurring theme of disillusionment with both the government and media, with commenters questioning their integrity and reliability.
  • Overall, the discussion reflects deep concerns about the ethical implications of AI-generated content, the erosion of trust in institutions, and the broader societal impact of deceptive practices in governance.
Composing APIs and CLIs in the LLM era
• Article: https://walters.app/blog/composing-apis-clis
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46722074
• Score: 64
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • The debate over LLM tool integration intensifies, with a shift toward enabling models to execute shell commands directly instead of relying on fine-grained tool calls. This approach allows for efficient command pipelines, reducing token costs and enabling reusable scripts.
  • • Tools like Restish and oauth2c exemplify a "no-code" philosophy by interpreting OpenAPI specs and simplifying OAuth 2.0 flows, replacing dense scripts with streamlined shell commands for API interactions.
  • • Reverse-engineering workflows using LLMs, such as creating Python clients from HAR files, demonstrates the potential for adversarial interoperability, empowering users to automate services even without official APIs.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. **Main Topics Discussed**:
  • • Tools and approaches for interacting with remote MCP servers and APIs using CLI, FUSE, and Bash.
  • • The use of large language models (LLMs) with APIs, particularly leveraging OpenAPI specifications and curl commands.
  • • Authentication challenges when using agents and CLI tools, including security concerns around credentials.
  • • Development of platforms and registries for AI tools, such as tpmjs.com, which provides multiple interaction methods (CLI, MCP, REST) for agents.
  • • Debate over the advantages and trade-offs of CLI tools versus MCPs, focusing on composability, schema enforcement, and reliability.
  • 2. **Key Themes**:
  • • CLI tools are widely appreciated for their composability, discoverability, and compatibility with LLMs. Several commenters view them as a natural interface for agents due to their simplicity and universality.
  • • Authentication remains a recurring challenge, with suggestions for proxy layers and scoped API tokens to address security issues.
  • • Structured data (as enforced by MCPs) is highlighted as crucial for building reliable pipelines, while CLI tools are noted for their flexibility but potential brittleness in complex scenarios.
  • • The role of standards like OpenAPI and JSON Schema is emphasized in ensuring consistency and reliability in API interactions.
  • 3. **Significant Agreements**:
  • • Many commenters agree on the utility of CLI tools for interacting with agents and APIs, particularly for their composability and ease of use.
  • • There is a shared sentiment that authentication and credential management are critical areas needing improvement.
  • • The importance of structured data and schema enforcement for reliable pipelines is acknowledged by several participants.
  • 4. **Disagreements**:
  • • Some commenters debate whether CLI tools or MCPs are better suited for interacting with agents, with arguments about composability versus structured data and reliability.
  • • One commenter expresses skepticism about the practical utility of current AI tooling advancements, criticizing the focus on creating text files (.md) over real-world software.
  • 5. **Overall Sentiment**:
  • • The discussion is largely constructive, with commenters sharing insights, tools, and approaches to improve agent and API interactions.
  • • There is some critical sentiment regarding the broader AI tooling ecosystem, particularly around the lack of impactful real-world applications.
  • 6. **Unique Insights**:
  • • Suggestions for using proxy layers to securely manage credentials and prevent direct access by agents.
  • • Innovative approaches like tpmjs.com, which offers multiple interaction modalities for agents and automates skill generation using LLMs.
  • • Observations on the natural compatibility of CLIs with LLMs due to their sequential nature and universality.
  • Overall, the discussion highlights practical challenges and solutions in the use of CLI tools, MCPs, and APIs for agents, with a focus on composability, security, and structured data.
The state of modern AI text to speech systems for screen reader users
• Article: https://stuff.interfree.ca/2026/01/05/ai-tts-for-screenreaders.html
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730346
• Score: 49
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • Despite advancements in AI-driven text-to-speech (TTS) technology, blind screen reader users remain underserved due to their unique needs for speed, clarity, and efficiency over natural-sounding voices. Popular systems like Eloquence, last updated in 2003, are outdated and difficult to maintain.
  • • Modern AI TTS models, such as Supertonic and Kitten TTS, face critical issues like dependency bloat, inaccuracy, slow response times, and lack of customization, making them unsuitable for screen readers.
  • • The community faces significant challenges in modernizing TTS systems for blind users, with potential solutions requiring millions in funding and expertise in linguistics, signal processing, and programming. Advocates hope for increased awareness and collaboration to address these gaps.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion revolves around the limitations and challenges of modern AI-based text-to-speech (TTS) systems, particularly in the context of screen readers used by blind individuals.
  • 2. A key theme is the mismatch between the goals of AI TTS systems and the specific needs of screen reader users. Commenters noted that while AI voices aim to sound natural and human-like, blind users prioritize speed, accuracy, and predictability, which modern systems often fail to deliver.
  • 3. Several commenters expressed frustration with AI TTS models, citing issues such as skipping words, mispronouncing numbers, generating garbled speech artifacts, and slower response times compared to legacy systems like Eloquence and ESpeak. These older systems, though outdated, are still favored by many blind users due to their efficiency and reliability.
  • 4. Some commenters provided technical insights into the limitations of current models, suggesting that implementation choices and architectural issues may be contributing to the problems. For instance, one commenter argued that modern systems could be optimized by tweaking chunk sizes for streaming, though this was debated by others.
  • 5. There is a general sentiment of concern and pessimism regarding the future of screen reader technology. Commenters highlighted the lack of overlap between modern TTS research and the needs of blind users, as well as the dwindling support for legacy systems. One commenter estimated that modernizing the preferred TTS stack would require significant funding and expertise, which seems unlikely to materialize.
  • 6. Broader accessibility issues were raised, such as the lack of support for screen readers in Linux Wayland environments and the proprietary protocols introduced by GNOME, which further complicate adoption. This has led some users to consider switching to Windows despite reservations.
  • 7. A few commenters proposed potential solutions, such as reverse-engineering older systems like Eloquence, though others pointed out the technical complexity and legal barriers involved.
  • 8. The sentiment across the discussion was mixed but leaned toward skepticism and disappointment. While some commenters praised the advancements in AI TTS models for general use, many agreed that these systems are not yet suitable for screen reader users and fail to address their unique requirements.
  • 9. One insightful comment suggested that AI's potential lies beyond improving screen readers and could instead serve as a conversational assistant for blind users, offering a more interactive and task-oriented experience.
  • 10. Overall, the discussion highlighted the gap between technological innovation in AI TTS and practical accessibility needs, with a consensus that significant improvements are required before these systems can effectively replace legacy solutions for screen readers.
Show HN: CLI for working with Apple Core ML models
• Article: https://github.com/schappim/coreml-cli
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46724565
• Score: 45
• Text-to-Speech audio: Listen
• AI-generated podcast: Listen
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • • CoreML-CLI is a native command-line interface designed for macOS, enabling users to inspect, run inference, benchmark, and manage Core ML models without requiring Xcode or Python. It supports tasks like model inspection, batch processing, performance benchmarking, and metadata management.
  • • The tool simplifies workflows with features such as concurrent batch execution and model compilation to optimized formats (.mlmodelc). It is compatible with macOS 13+ and supports both Apple Silicon and Intel Macs.
  • • Built using Swift and Apple's Core ML framework, CoreML-CLI enhances efficiency for developers working with machine learning models while offering seamless integration into macOS environments.

Discussion Highlights:

  • 1. The discussion revolves around a tool or functionality related to Core ML models and its capabilities. Commenters are exploring its features and potential use cases.
  • 2. One commenter expressed interest in trying the tool over the weekend and sought information about Core ML model names, indicating a curiosity about its practical applications.
  • 3. Another commenter asked whether the tool supports conversion and quantization from PyTorch or if it is strictly for running existing Core ML files. This reflects a focus on its technical scope and compatibility.
  • 4. A reply clarified that the tool does not handle conversion or quantization directly but pointed out that Apple provides a Python library called "coremltools," which supports conversion from frameworks like PyTorch, TensorFlow/TF Lite, and ONNX. A link to the library was shared, adding valuable context and resources to the discussion.
  • 5. The overall sentiment of the comments is positive and inquisitive, with participants showing interest in exploring the tool's capabilities and sharing helpful information.
CEOs Say AI Is Making Work More Efficient. Employees Tell a Different Story
• Article: https://www.wsj.com/lifestyle/workplace/ceos-say-ai-is-making-work-more-efficient-employees-tell-a-different-story-6613ce9d
• HN Discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46728781
• Score: 42
You can listen to the audio and podcast with better experience on aicrafter.info.

Article Summary:

  • No relevant content found

Discussion Highlights:

  • • The discussion revolves around the role and impact of AI in various contexts, including corporate decision-making, development workflows, and efficiency improvements.
  • • **Corporate decision-making and AI**: One commenter suggests that AI helps CEOs make quicker decisions by reducing the amount of information they need to process, though the actual choice (yes or no) may not matter much. Another commenter notes that C-suite executives are inherently biased, with a reply highlighting that workers may also hold biases against AI.
  • • **AI's current stage and challenges**: A commenter describes AI as being in a "painful growth stage," where its outcomes are unpredictable—sometimes significantly improving efficiency but other times leading to poor results. This aligns with another comment that characterizes AI as a "force multiplier," amplifying both good and bad outcomes, making it hard to determine its net value.
  • • **AI's impact on developers**: One developer mentions that AI hasn't saved them time directly but has allowed them to expand their scope to tasks like documentation and prototyping, which they wouldn't have prioritized otherwise. A reply points out that this reflects a shift in expectations rather than a true time-saving benefit.
  • • **Learning curve and errors in AI usage**: While one commenter argues that AI efficiency improves significantly with experience, another disagrees, stating that AI still produces too many errors to be fully reliable and compares its utility to Stack Overflow at its peak.
  • • **Sentiment**: The overall sentiment is mixed, with some recognizing AI's potential to improve efficiency and scope, while others highlight its limitations, unpredictability, and error-prone nature. There is no clear consensus on whether AI is a net positive or negative at this stage.
  • • **Notable insights**: AI is described as a tool that amplifies both strengths and weaknesses, and its effectiveness depends heavily on the context and the user's ability to manage its outputs.

contributed roughly the same amount to </span><em>net-new</em><span> GDP.</span></p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">To keep things in perspective, though, consumer spending accounts for ~70% of total GDP, so it’s still a much bigger part of the picture than Capex (and it’s not really close).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;"><span>When it comes to </span><em>growth</em><span>, however, AI is the pro-cycle now, comprising an historically large share of total private investment.</span></p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>The chart speaks for itself. There is some debate about how to precisely account for the AI Capex contribution to GDP, but pretty much everyone seems to agree that it’s a very big deal, driving growth in the technology sector, but also in utilities and industrials. Other than healthcare, which is generally considered acyclical, AI Capex appears to be the main event.</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Well, we can’t really say that consumers are buying OnlyFans for the articles. iOS apps in the app store.</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">After basically zero growth for the past three years, new app releases surged 60% yoy in December (and 24% on a trailing twelve month basis).</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">It’s starting to feel like 2008, when Apple first released the iPhone SDK (now called the iOS SDK). While it initially debuted with approximately 500 third-party apps, app downloads surpassed 1M in the first weekend (and reached ~1B by early 2009). More apps drew more eyeballs which drew more apps, all of which eventually unlocked hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue for app developers (and a multi-trillion dollar ecosystem that no one had ever heard of a decade prior).</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">AI is similarly opening up an entirely new surface area for value creation, and mobile is emerging as an early winner on the frontier.</p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height: 26px;"><hr style="margin: 32px 0;padding: 0;height: 1px;background: rgb(0,0,0,.1);border: style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Microsoft released an “AI Diffusion” map, demonstrating the share of the working age population using a generative AI application during the second half of 2025. While adoption is increasingly widespread, there is a clear regional divergence such that “adoption in the Global North grew nearly twice as fast as in the Global South.”</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">Somewhat surprisingly, the UAE sits atop the leaderboard (followed closely by Singapore), with ~64% of the working age population adopting AI (at least once, during the measured period).</p></li><li style="margin: 8px 0 0 32px;mso-special-format: bullet;"><p style="color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;margin-bottom: 0;box-sizing: border-box;padding-left: 4px;font-size: 16px;margin: 0;">The US, for its part, increased adoption by ~2 percentage points since the first half of the year, but actually slipped a spot in the rankings from 23rd to 24th (following a big jump by South Korea).</p></li></ul><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;">Microsoft points out that AI adoption is hard to measure, so this is really just one way of looking at the picture, but it’s striking nonetheless.</p><p style="margin: 0 0 20px 0;color: rgb(54,55,55);line-height: 26px;font-size: 16px;"><span>Adoption is increasing pretty much everywhere, with roughly the entirety of the OECD demonstrating at least 20% adoption. If the adoption gap continues to widen, though, one can only imagine that the second- and third-order effects of being an “AI have v. AI have-not” will be amplified.</span><span class="footnote-anchor-email" data-component-name="FootnoteAnchorToDOMStatic" style="font-size: 20px;">³</span></p><div style="font-size: 16px;line-height:
